1.question: What is the impact of weaker solvation on the first and second voltage plateaus of Li-S batteries, according to the study?

options.A: Higher first plateau and lower second plateau.
options.B: Lower first plateau and higher second plateau.
options.C: No impact on either voltage plateau.
options.D: Higher first plateau and higher second plateau.
options.E: Lower first plateau and lower second plateau.

2.question: Which method was primarily used to measure the solvation free energy in this study?

options.B: Potentiometric measurement.
options.C: Calorimetry.
options.D: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy.

3.question: How does the addition of tetrafluoroethyl and tetrafluoropropyl ether (TTE) to an electrolyte influence solvation energy?

options.A: It increases solvation energy, indicating weaker solvation.
options.B: It decreases solvation energy, indicating stronger solvation.
options.C: It has no effect on solvation energy.
options.D: It fluctuates solvation energy randomly.
options.E: It stabilizes solvation energy, keeping it constant.

4.question: What technique was used to quantify the solubility of lithium polysulphides (LiPS) in the electrolytes?

options.B: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM).
options.C: Ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) spectroscopy.
options.D: Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR).

5.question: What was observed in the diffusivity of Li+ ions in DME compared to DME-TTE mixtures?

options.A: DME shows lower Li+ diffusivity than DME-TTE.
options.B: DME shows higher Li+ diffusivity than DME-TTE.
options.C: DME and DME-TTE have the same Li+ diffusivity.
options.D: Li+ diffusivity is not affected by the solvent.
options.E: TTE significantly increases diffusivity more than DME.

6.question: Which electrolyte parameter was found to correlate with cycling Coulombic efficiency and initial discharge capacity?

options.B: Thermal stability of the electrolyte.
options.C: Solvation free energy.
options.D: Electrolyte density.

7.question: What was the observed impact of weaker solvation on the solubility of lithium polysulphides?

options.B: Decreased solubility.
options.C: No change in solubility.
options.D: Random fluctuations in solubility.

8.question: How does solvation free energy of Li+ relate to the natural logarithm of the solubility constant (Ksp)?

options.A: Solvation free energy is directly proportional to ln(Ksp).
options.B: Solvation free energy is inversely proportional to ln(Ksp).
options.C: Solvation free energy has no relationship with ln(Ksp).
options.D: Solvation free energy is the square of ln(Ksp).
options.E: Solvation free energy is the same as ln(Ksp).

9.question: What was used as a reference electrolyte in the potentiometric solvation free energy measurements?

options.B: 3 M LiTFSI in DOL-DME.
options.C: 1 M LiTFSI DME.
options.D: 1 M LiFSI DEC.

10.question: What was the core objective of the molecular dynamics simulations conducted in this study?

options.A: To measure the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte.
options.B: To compare the clustering behavior of Li+ in different solvation environments.
options.C: To determine the viscosity of the solvent.
options.D: To analyze thermal stability of the electrolyte.
options.E: To calculate the electrochemical window of the system.

11.question: What is a key finding regarding the correlation between solvation free energy and Li metal anode performance?

options.A: Stronger solvation leads to superior Li metal performance.
options.B: Weaker solvation leads to superior Li metal performance.
options.C: Solvation energy has no impact on Li metal performance.
options.D: Fluctuating solvation energy enhances Li metal performance.
options.E: Balanced solvation energy ensures stable Li metal performance.

12.question: Which solvents were employed in the study for preparing ether-based electrolytes?

options.B: DME, G4, DOL, THF.
options.C: Dimethoxyethane and benzene.
options.D: Methanol and ethanol.

13.question: In the context of Li-S batteries, what role does the electrolyte play due to the presence of solvated lithium polysulphides?

options.A: The electrolyte has no role in the reaction dynamics.
options.B: It only serves as an electron conductor.
options.C: It heavily affects the full-cell thermodynamics.
options.D: It acts as a thermal insulator.

options.B: Weaker solvation had no effect on CE.
options.C: Weaker solvation increased the CE.
options.D: Weaker solvation led to random variations in CE.

options.B: LiPF6.
options.C: LiBF4.
options.D: LiTFSI.

16.question: What causes a decrease in polysulphide solubility as per the findings of this study?

options.B: Weaker solvation.
options.C: Higher electrolyte concentration.
options.D: Lowering potential.

17.question: What is the significance of the two voltage plateaus in the discharge voltage profiles of Li-S batteries?

options.A: They indicate the end of battery life.
options.B: They represent the transformation of different sulphur compounds.
options.C: They show the mechanical strength of the battery.
options.D: They are unrelated to the battery chemistry.

options.A: It measures the thermal conductivity of the electrolyte.
options.B: It governs the minimum work needed for solvation.
options.C: It is unrelated to the performance of the electrolyte.
options.D: It is used to measure the electrode resistance.
options.E: It relates to the optical clarity of the electrolyte.

options.B: Weaker solvation increases CE.
options.C: Solvation has no effect on CE.
options.D: Medium solvation gives the highest CE.

options.B: Do not affect polysulphide solubility.
options.C: Lead to lower polysulphide solubility.
